https://realpython.com/python-string-formatting/#1-old-style-string-formatting-operator
this should not be an error, finding the loadbalancer in PENDING_UPDATE is ok, as long as it is not stuck there forever

Perhaps a better idea would be to move the check of the status outside of the loop, so that if we still see pending update after our timeout we would place appropriate error message and raise exception. Or am I talking nonsense?

No need to trigger these operations of removing the loadbalancer and the reference of it on the KuryrLoadBalancer CRD as once the Load Balancer is stuck at this point it's not possible to perform any operation on it.

THis is currently a bug on Octavia https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2008338

What Roman suggested makes complete sense. This check can be moved out of the loop and we can just return nothing when the condition is matched. Also, a warning might be a better fit for the LOG message instead of debug.

This check shouldn't be before the loop, it should be after. If we keep it here it would never check what we want which is the LB status is still pending_update after there is no provisioning time remaining (in other words stuck on pending_updtae)
perhaps worth to mention that it is "stuck on PENDING_UPDATE for too long". There is also the option for the loadbalancer to be stuck on PENDING_DELETE, this should be considered too
is it "None" what we want to return in this situation? If that so I would add a note about it to explain why
sorry, one more nit, use the status var here to only print the real status the loadbalancer is stuck in
same here, no need 1, just {}, also, add a space between "status," and "loadbalancer['id'])"

Seems the CI is not happy with the changes? I took a quick look at https://zuul.openstack.org/status#789052

It will complain that this line is too long and there are also some other issue that can be checked by just running 'tox -e pep8' or 'tox -e py36'.

We still want to raise ResourceNotReady if this happens, as it will allow us to retry in other nested handler [1]. RetryHandler makes sure the event is retried blocking the handler execution so that events are processed in order. This is okay, we don't want to process next events before the Octavia finishes modifying LB for the current ones.

The problem is when this times out here [2]. The message is ambiguous - just ResourceNotReady: <lb-name>. This isn't useful for the user.

I think the best way to do it is to create a new subclass of ResourceNotReady exception class [3] - we can call it LoadBalancerNotReady. This exception should make sure to build the message differently - i.e. instead of just

 super(ResourceNotReady, self).__init__("Resource not ready: %r" % msg)

something like:

 super().__init__("Octavia is misbehaving, loadbalancer %s is stuck in %s state for %d seconds. Please contact your OpenStack administrator." % (lb_name, lb_state, seconds))

Does it make sense?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/de6a06c6f7854ca9b0cd698f472964efdc8141b8/kuryr_kubernetes/handlers/retry.py#L58-L99
[2] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/de6a06c6f7854ca9b0cd698f472964efdc8141b8/kuryr_kubernetes/handlers/retry.py#L90-L95
[3] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/d0331abc38b4713b710014d633333dfc95aafc58/kuryr_kubernetes/exceptions.py#L27-L38

cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/powermax/.message:
I am getting the following from pep8. 
./cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/powermax/common.py:3871:5: C901 'PowerMaxCommon._migrate_volume' is too complex (31)

C901
Functions that are deemed too complex are functions that have too much branching logic. Branching logic includes if/elif/else and for/while loops.

It is a large method so is a candidate for refactoring for readability.
It would be a slight optimization to move this to after the 'if snapshots' block -- you only have to make this REST API call in the event that there are no snapshots.
This is a much better name -- way more clear about what's going on in this function.

this looks like an accident waiting to happen because the caller has to know the exact position of each value.  A lightweight way to make this safer would be something like this:

    from collections import namedtuple
    def _get_replication_flags(args):
        rf = namedtuple('ReplicationFlags',
                        'was_rep_enabled, is_rep_enabled, '
                        'backend_ids_differ, rep_mode, target_extra_specs')
        # load it up using your current logic
        rf.was_rep_enabled = True
        rf.is_rep_enabled = False
        rf.backend_ids_differ = True
        rf.rep_mode = 'fancy rep'
        rf.target_extra_specs = {'k1':'v1', 'k2':'v2'}
        return rf

then at lines 3907-3910 you could do

    flags = _get_replication_flags(args)

and then use flags.was_rep_enabled, etc., throughout the rest of the function.

Thanks for the feedback Brian and Gorka.  This was a first pass refactor as I had issues with the original method being to large and complicated.  Any feedback to improve, most appreciated.
Some of the other refactored methods below also return tuples, so I am assuming a similar tactic here.

I think it's a good idea, but if this is implemented I think the named tuple should be declared globally (as if it were a class) so it can be easily reused.

    from collections import namedtuple
    ReplicationFlags = namedtuple('ReplicationFlags',
                                  'was_rep_enabled, is_rep_enabled, '
                                  'backend_ids_differ, rep_mode, target_extra_specs')

    def _get_replication_flags(args):
        rf = ReplicationFlags(was_rep_enabled=True,
                              is_rep_enabled=False,
                              backend_ids_differ=True,
                              rep_mode='fancy rep',
                              target_extra_specs={'k1':'v1', 'k2':'v2'})
        return rf

The reason for that is that with that implementation is treating the subclass returned by namedtuple as an instance, and it is forcefully replacing the subclass' properties (was_rep_enabled, is_resp_enabled, etc) with values.

Suggested implementation is no different than doing this:

  rf = namedtuple('RF', [])
  rf.was_rep_enabled = True
  rf.is_rep_enabled = False
  rf.anythinggoes = 123

After all a tuple should not change its values after it has been created.

PS: Brian's code works fine btw.

swift/cli/relinker.py.message:
The nuances between os.exit and os._exit really threw me this arvo... Fun times :P

But seeing as the signal is telling it to all close up, the extra work in os.exit seems to make it all behave properly, especially when trying to test it all.

This is letting us return the right return code when we exit from a signal handler, without it I could never get EXIT_SIGNAL to return properly in the tests.

Maybe I just need fresh eyes, so will look again in the morning.

I think I'd be OK with using EXIT_ERROR -- it exited abnormally, so we have to assume there's still work to be done.

Or -- we've already got some handling for workers exiting after receiving a signal... what if we do something like

 signal.signal(sig, signal.SIG_DFL)
 os.kill(os.getpid(), sig)

?

oh yeah, so daemon is killing the process group. Ie, os.killpg(0) which must map to the one it's running in.

I guess the question is do we want to kill all children/members of the pg on a signal, or allow us to signal individual processes.

I'm wary of logging inside a signal handler -- there's a lock used throughout logging that could cause a deadlock if it's held by something other than the main thread when the signal gets processed.

OTOH, this should all be single-threaded, right? Likely have multiple processes, but each should have just the one thread...
yeah as it currenty stands because we're using fork they all should be extra signle threaded processes right. Although yeah, happy to remove the logging if it's an issue.

This is a pretty different approach to signal handlers compared to what we do in wsgi and daemon, where we might set a flag or signal children then get out. Not saying it's necessarily bad, just want to think through the reason we do it that way currently and whether it'd be better for us to follow precedent.

If we really want to kill ourselves from the signal handler, I think we might need to use os._exit() so unit tests can pass.

Fair enough, yeah I'll have a look at what were doing over there.

Actually I needed to change this from os._exit() to os.exit() so the tests would actaully behave themselves. os._exit() seems to kill straight away with no cleanup. Where as os.exit() behaved correctly so it could be caught and run through the finally.
We've lost the traceback -- have we seen IOErrors popping that bomb out the whole process? Where did they bubble up from?
oh really this is my bad.. it's bubling up from tests, I was firing them to test signals we don't catch. Maybe I just need to mock some more so I can bail cleaner.

manifests/function/dex-aio/dex-helmrelea.message: since this already matches the default, what is the purpose of adding it? if we intend to override it via the ReplacementTransformer can't we do that without explicitly adding it here, since the parameter already exists via the chart's values.yaml interface?

I assume this was the sole of discussion we had on call related to replica, where we wanted to have an additional parameter explicitely specified for replica in HelmRelease and thats why Larry added comments
 - Dex pod replica count

Since the parameter exists in the chart itself, what we are specifying here is a values override of that parameter, and the only reason to do that is if we want to actually override the value to be different than the default e.g. 2.

After discussing with Sean, we agree that we can leave the default replica count of 1 which would mean we would not need this change.  Site-specific or sub-cluster-specific manifests could use a kustomize patch to override that default replica count.

.zuul.d/jobs.yaml.message:
I think it would be best if either
a) the job name continues to be explicit about the release or...
b) we do not hard-code the release here, signaling it is *expected* to be latest, as it would need to be updated every 6 months (Fedora release cadence). A bump to the default DIB_RELEASE would likewise be needed as well.

Also, since Fedora supports 2 released versions and so does DIB (at least up to now), we should probably keep testing the latest 2 released versions in CI matching what we have for CentOS, Ubuntu, Debian, etc, hence I lean to option a).

Another option, or rather complementing to option b), is to instead use the "latest" container tag that points to latest released version (34 as of today).
https://hub.docker.com/_/fedora?tab=tags&page=1&ordering=last_updated&name=latest
agree and will add the release into the name.
Sticking with option a) makes sense to me since the container file stuff seems to be explicit about versions too.

just wondering where this comes from can we arbitrarily choose whatever we want here and ovb will create ports with that address?

seems like 'fa:16:3a' must be a specially chosen prefix since it doesn't match any existing organisation unique identifier from a quick search just now

fa = 11111010
             ^ second bit is 1, i.e its a locally administered MAC address.

The second bit of the first byte of a MAC address determines the type of OUI. If the bit is 0 then it is an OUI globally assigned by the IEEE; if the bit is 1 then it is a locally administered MAC address. [1]

  Neutron by default uses fa:16:3e as it's base for generating MAC addresses for VIF's.
  This uses               fa:16:3a
                                 ^ i.e not in conflict with neutron.


Since it's a locally administered MAC address, and it's not colliding with what neutron uses by default I think we should be good.



[1] http://www.noah.org/wiki/MAC_address#locally_administered_address

thank you I didn't know about the 'locally administered mac address' obviously it makes sense for 'virtual' ethernet cards/ports 

so it isn't arbitrary and there is also no chance of a collision with an IEEE assigned/globally unique oui

manifests/init.pp.message:
The code from L475..L486 highlights a general point I want to make. I realize castellan is a generic key manager interface and barbican is just one specific implementation. Creating a new cinder::key_manager class makes sense from an absraction standpoint, but the code changes introduce a lot of churn if, in reality, everyone plans to use barbican.

In other words, I think we can reduce code churn *today* by defering until a time when there's an actual need for key manager other than barbican.
You make good points, thank you.

Yeah. I found the same when I was creating this patch, but because of the following reasons I decided the current implementation which would required multiple new classes.

1.
If we merge key_manager and barbican into the same class, it becomes difficult to determine the safe but reasonable names.
For example if we implement the single key_manager class then we should prefix all barbican parameters with barbican_* to avoid unexpected collisions in the future. But this requires us to have ugly barbican_barbican_* parameters or maintain complicated parameter mappings.

2.
I think from cinder's perspective vault is another option (though personally I've never seen it used)

3.
AFAIK castellan is used in 3 projects, nova, cinder and glance currently, and it's better to have the consistent implementation among them. Since each service can implement some customization (for example nova has its own implementation of key manager), I feel it's better to depend on the structure of library instead of usage of each services, otherwise we would need to adjust implementations in all projects if one of these project make any change affecting the structure we'll put.
The deprecation warnings at L475 and L480 look fine, but maybe move L478 so all the includes are grouped together.
I suggest moving this into key_manager class. I'll add another comment there.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message: if reserved is a large value, wouldn't this make hp_mem_avail_mib smaller, and thus more likely to have condition met?  (As I understood, the 50% value was chosen to allow for a conservative check so that a resize is not increased unless there's sufficient memory).

Well, yes, if the reserved gets big, the mem_avail will be less than 50% of total memory and then the hugepages adjustment will occur. And as you said this was chosen to be conservative, maybe a tighter value would be better, but would we expect to have the reserved that is around 8GB for a AIO-DX to increase that much? The total memory in my test was 55GB and there was still lots of room for the scenario, on the lab reported on the Bug it was 120GB.
Ok, as per discussion, intent is if there's sufficient memory capacity, the huge page memory is preserved; rather than potentially adjusted downwards.

python-k8sapp-nginx-ingress-controller/k.message:
Please remove this line. The framework already logs this:

sysinv 2021-05-12 01:01:55.203 137378 INFO sysinv.conductor.kube_app [-] lifecycle hook for application nginx-ingress-controller (1.1-15) started {'lifecycle_type': u'operation', 'relative_timing': u'post', 'mode': u'manual', 'operation': u'upload', 'extra': {}}.

sysinv 2021-05-12 01:02:06.248 137378 INFO sysinv.conductor.kube_app [-] lifecycle hook for application nginx-ingress-controller (1.1-15) started {'lifecycle_type': u'check', 'relative_timing': u'pre', 'mode': u'manual', 'operation': u'apply', 'extra': {}}.

sysinv 2021-05-12 01:02:06.280 137378 INFO sysinv.conductor.kube_app [-] lifecycle hook for application nginx-ingress-controller (1.1-15) started {'lifecycle_type': u'operation', 'relative_timing': u'pre', 'mode': u'manual', 'operation': u'apply', 'extra': {}}.

sysinv 2021-05-12 01:49:47.914 89692 INFO sysinv.conductor.kube_app [-] lifecycle hook for application nginx-ingress-controller (1.1-15) started {'lifecycle_type': u'check', 'relative_timing': u'pre', 'mode': u'manual', 'operation': u'mtc-action', 'extra': {'app_status': u'applied', 'action': u'unlock'}}.

Revert this to be the last step in the function, instead of the first step.
Reasoning is that there are, and may be added, hooks that interrupt the flow of execution(example: automatic semantic check that rejects the auto apply). To override them you need to call the overrides before this
Please remove this line or change to LOG.debug. This only helps during development to verify that the correct conditions for the hook were put in place(the if checks before the function call).

It is the job of on app to create it's necessary resources. Nginx app only requires a secret present in kube-system namespace. Indeed the secret inside the kube-system may be created outside the app applies itself as a preparation step. To me it seems like the secret in kube-system acts like a cache and not an original source.

My suggestion is at least call the super before 'return self.pre_apply(app)' not for each hook and still leave the final super in place to go to default behavior for untreated hooks.

Or simply add 'lifecycle_utils.create_local_registry_secrets(app_op, app, hook_info)' since an app should create it's resources.

So if I create the Secret, should I also delete it when the app is removed? 

I can do the changes to do that but it seems to me the registry Secret in kube-system is a system-wide resource, not a nginx-ingress-controller resource.

I'll make the change to call 'lifecycle_utils.create_local_registry_secrets' here.
No need, the delete_local_registry_secrets will be called when super is called. It won't do anything in this case.

oslo_utils/imageutils.py.message:
weird indentation. Also, the commit message could be more concise. How about:

    Support for the 'human' format will be removed in a future release.

?

Nit: I'm proposing that we remove the format kwarg completely, not just the 'human' value. Also, if we do what I propose below this could read something more like: 'Overriding the qemu-img output format is no longer supported. The format kwarg will be removed in a future release.'
I agree, my message could be ambiguous.

My thought was that we just remove this completely now. There should be no externally visible changes since we're parsing the human-readable values into plain bytes anyway (which again makes me wonder why human was ever an option...). Also, since human is broken in recent versions of qemu it's unlikely that forcing json would make things any worse for existing human users.

I think remove this now is a little bit an abrupt change,  how to manage case where given input is still to `human` format?

In this case json loader will fail, we could catch exceptions but what we should return to users in this case?

I think we should deprecate first during a short period to allow smooth migration for users and their inputs (changing command, etc...) and then completely drop this code and the `format` param in a second time.

This isn't ideal. Either we provide format='json' and get this warning, or we don't provide this which means we get human format and the below warning.

Perhaps we could deprecate the human format now and deprecate the parameter when the human format deprecation is complete?
Sorry for the long delay, this topic was fall in a black hole in my universe, I'll address your comments soons.

Yeah, I think if we don't want to break consumers we have to do it in 3 steps:

1. Deprecate the human format
2. Remove the human format, ignore the parameter value and deprecate the parameter
3. Remove the parameter

service-mgmt/sm/src/sm_failover_failed_s.message: I will assume that the 'delete node' calls above will be restored if we return any errors from this point onward, by the sm_failover_failed_process_restart  method (which calls sm_node_api_update_node) ?

The delete node will not be restored. The peer will be added back only when mtc-agent tells SM so. There are only 2 exits for a node being in "failed" state, a) is to be terminated by sm_failover_failed_process_restart (recovered), or b) to be restarted (entire node) by peer node when it can (to be recovered).

this loop makes no difference than sleep(10), it is a blocking call for current thread, and yield processor to any other threads. I just made no change to the existing code.

It's fine in our case (we don't have a good localization story anyway), but in theory we should respect the caller's headers. No action required, just mentioning it for completeness.
OK

Ugh. UGH. Wait, it doesn't seem to be true, AttributeRegistry actually specifies the fields: https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/AttributeRegistry.v1_3_4.json. I don't suggest we add them as separate columns to the database, but it seems that we can decide on a subset of fields we support.

This can include default_value, immutable, unique, lower_bound, max_length, min_length, read_only (wtf, why is it different from immutable??), reset_required, possible_values, value_expression and upper_bound (and write_only?). Maybe also display_name and help_text.

This is especially important for potential non-Redfish implementations.

Good point. Changed to define the common set of attribute fields defined in the schema which Sushy will set when caching the registry.

We should also be able to use these registry fields to validate the BIOS settings in clean steps to verify attribute names, allowable values, ranges (and if readonly in particular!) etc. when setting BIOS attributes. Its not really applicable to this spec but possible for a follow-on.
I'm not found of a free-form API output. As proposed above, let's settle down on a subset of fields.
Updated to only include the subset of fields in "Data model impact".
Well actually, we're talking about not making them vendor dependent here. We can add normal fields and default them to NULL/None.
Done
Let's also support 'fields', I can easily imagine that someone won't want to fetch help_text.

OK, added text for this.  Note that I've removed help_text in addition to display_name. Help_text can be very long for certain vendors - one or two paragraphs, and probably not worth storing. Display_name is practically just the attribute name split into separate words in order to show on a menu and does not provide much value to an API.

Since the language localization is only used for HelpText and DisplayName (all other fields are always in English) I removed that also.
I'd prefer not to have a nested field. At the very least it prevents us from adding meaningful --fields query.
As we talked about, changed this to remove the ''registry'' nesting and now all fields will be at the same level which will allow queries.

I would also like us to switch to using underscores instead of camel case for consistency with the rest of Ironic.

And AttributeName is duplicated with name.
Done
I'd rename this to allowed_values to avoid confusing with the existing value
Done
just name
Done
just display_name
As per the earlier comment I also removed the the display_name here as it provides little value.
I actually wonder if we need a new method, or we can cache the schema in the same call where we collect the data.
Removed the new method, will get the data in ``cache_bios_settings``.
If you're not going to expose ValueDisplayName, maybe create a normal list? ["Enabled", "Disabled"]?

Good idea. Some vendors include both ValueName and DisplayValueName in the response while one in particular only includes DisplayValueName (and not ValueName) so a simple list would hide that.

Fixed.
We should probably expose detail there.
Openstacksdk does not currently support BIOS settings. I've added a note that adding support isn't required for this functionality, but when its added the detail info should also be included.
